Award.AwardTitle: Engineering Highly Specific and Orthogonal CRISPR-Cas Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1403135
Beisel, Chase L.

An organism's genome provides the blueprints for all cellular functions and behaviors. Accordingly, editing the genome is an essential step toward understanding and controlling any of these activities. A powerful method of genome editing recently became available with the discovery of prokaryotic defense systems. While these tools have been used to genetically engineer diverse organisms, these natural editing systems are constrained in the types of DNA sequences that can be targeted and their ability to function independently if more than one system is present. To overcome these limitations, this project seeks to engineer editing systems that are more flexible and that can act independently. The resulting systems have the potential to transform how genome editing is performed in all forms of life, thereby driving efforts to understand the basis of genetic diseases and to engineer microbes that can produce chemicals sustainably. Insights from these efforts will also help reveal how the components of these systems interact with each other and how the assembled systems identify DNA targets. Beyond these scientific advances, this project will train the next generation of scientists and engineers to harness natural biological processes as tools for studying and engineering biology. This project will also integrate topics on gene editing systems into existing coursework for undergraduate and graduate students and expand a campus-wide biotechnology seminar series to include local industry representatives and students from surrounding schools.

The long-term goal of this research is to generate tools that permit facile, affordable, and efficient genome manipulation of any organism. CRISPR-Cas systems offer one of the most promising tools, yet each system can only target DNA sequences flanked by a DNA motif called a PAM. Furthermore, many of these systems utilize the same CRISPR RNAs responsible for target recognition, preventing the use of multiple systems at one time. To address these particular challenges, this project will generate orthogonal CRISPR-Cas systems that recognize different PAMs. These variants will be generated based on a well-characterized CRISPR-Cas system and a unique selection scheme that couples bacteriophage resistance and genome targeting. The resulting collection of evolved variants can specifically target diverse DNA sequences and can be implemented together without any crosstalk. As a proof-of-principle demonstration of their functionality, multiple variants will be simultaneously introduced into the dairy-culturing bacterium S. thermophilus for the combinatorial regulation of exopolysaccharide genes associated with yogurt texture.

This project is co-funded by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division and by the Synthetic and Systems Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cell Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funded project aimed to characterize and alter DNA cutting by CRISPR-Cas immune systems. These systems are naturally found in bacteria and archaea, yet they have also been the source of revolutionary tools for editing DNA sequences in different organisms—whether in humans to correct genetic diseases, in industrial microbes used to sustainably produce chemicals and fuels, or in crop plants to boost desirable traits. As part of the work, the group made a number of important discoveries and advances that have helped drive the use of CRISPR-Cas systems as technologies. One important outcome was showing that one of the most common types of systems can be easily converted from a DNA cutter to a DNA binder. Binding in the vicinity of a gene can block its expression, allowing the group to turn off one or multiple genes at will using the converted system. The group showed that the system present in the industrial workhorse Escherichia coli could be easily co-opted for this purpose, allowing us to repurpose this immune system to turn off multiple genes important for chemical production without killing the bacterium. The group also showed that the size and shape of the resulting CRISPR protein machinery could be readily tuned by varying the length of the RNA responsible for guiding the machinery to a target gene. Another important outcome was characterizing how the CRISPR protein machinery recognizes this guide RNA and what allows the machinery to recognize some RNAs but not others—an important consideration when using multiple CRISPR technologies at once. Finally, the group established a new technique for characterizing CRISPR-Cas systems based on cell-free transcription-translation systems. These systems can greatly accelerate how quickly a given system can be characterized as well as how many can be characterized at one time. Overall, the work led to multiple scientific, peer-reviewed publications, including two research publications in Molecular Cell and two research publications in Nucleic Acids Research.

Aside from the scientific advances, we also helped connect scientific advances to education and professional development of students. We hosted a university-wide seminar series called Biolunch that featured talks by graduate students through each summer. The PI also participated as an instructor for the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory summer course on Synthetic Biology. As part of the course, the PI taught an international group of academics and industrial scientists how to apply CRISPR technologies. Finally, the project supported one postdoctoral fellow and a set of graduate students as they developed an expertise in CRISPR technologies and how these technologies can be used to benefit society.
